resource.chars:
14 
<u>Teeth<\u> 
The ovine and Caprine affinities visible in the skull of the 
Musk Sheep are visible also in the teeth, the upper true 
molars are differentiated from those of Bison and Buffalo 
by the stoutness and prominence of the three principal 
costae and the small develop<s>e<\s>ment of the two secondary 
ones, the crowns also of the teeth are not so broad. On the 
internal aspect there is no accessory column which would 
at once separate them from Bos, Bubalus and Bison. 
There is a small accessory valley at the inner interspace 
between the two principal ones which is present also in Bos 
Caffir. <s>which<\s> It is absent from many of the oxen, and is in 
the Musk Sheep invariable larger and deeper than in 
any of the true Bovidae. A strong process passes from 
the inner side of the valley in <u>Premolar 4<\u> diagonally back-
-wards as far as its external border. not status[?] The anterior edge 
of the first premolar (P.M.2) is much sharper than in any 
of the Bovidae and differs in the simplicity of its 
crown from that of <u>Bubalus Caffir<\u>. The lower jaw 
teeth differ from those of oxen, in the  length of the 
anterior costa and by its being continued past the 
cingulum; by the fusion of the posterior valley in 
Molar 3 with the 2<sup>nd<\sup>, by the narrowness of the 
flesh. In Premolars 4 and 3 also, the posterior lobe is 
much more clearly defined. in other respects the lower 
dentition is closely allied to that in the domestic ox. 
The form of the lower jaw is essentially ovine or caprine 
& differing from those of Ox or Bison in the proportions which 
are given in the measurements. 
The vertebrae have been <s>done<\s> described and framed so admirably by Sir John Rich-
ardson in the Zoology of the Herald pp 72 - 89 that
